3.  Accidental Release Prevention Program
Frederickson Power complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable aqua ammonia storage and handling codes.  All employees involved with the operation or maintenance of the aqua ammonia system are thoroughly trained using Frederickson Power's documented training program.

4.  Five-Year Accident History
No accidental releases of aqua ammonia causing on-site or off-site injury or damage have occurred during the life of this facility.

5.  Emergency Response Program
Frederickson Power's emergency response program is based upon an accidental release of aqua ammonia.  We have discussed this program with the Pierce County Emergency Management and the local Fire Department. 

The following minor changes have taken place since the last RMP submission in June of 2014:

1.  An ammonia pressure switch was replaced with a pressure transmitter (Sept. 2014).

2.  Cooling capability was added to ammonia pump suction lines (April 2018).

3.  Ammonia piping modifications were made where diameters were increased, and the number of elbows were reduced.  This reduced flow resistance within the system and minimized the potential for fugitive emissions (April 2016).

4.  Sun screens were added near the tank and near associated piping.  This reduced radiant heat loading minimizing the chances of pressure build-up and the potential for fugitive emissions (April 2016).

5.  A new security camera system was added at the main entrance of the facility.  Site entries are now made through video identification and remote control of the gate (Dec. 2018).

6.  A new GHS compliant Safety Data Sheet was received from the supplier, Dyno Nobel (May 2015).

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
PER 40CFR 68.155(a) 


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
Frederickson Power in Tacoma, Washington handles aqua ammonia that is considered hazardous by EPA.  The toxicity of ammonia at high concentrations make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, and to reduce the threat to the personal health of our employees as well as nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.   Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia, the safety devices inherent in the design of the facility, combined with the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.

Frederickson Power's emergency response program is designed to effectively respond to an accidental release of ammonia.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC), the Washington Department of Ecology, and the National Response Center.

2.  The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The primary purpose of the generating station is to produce electric power from combustion of natural gas.  Aqua ammonia is used at the facility to reduce the concentration of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) produced during combustion.  Aqua ammonia is received by truck and stored as a liquid in one storage tank.  The aqua ammonia is pumped to an evaporator and then injected into the combustion system where it reacts with the natural gas combustion products to reduce NOx concentrations.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The regulated substance handled at this facility is aqua ammonia.  The maximum amount of aqua ammonia that can be stored at this station is 9,600 gallons or 71,824 pounds (although the storage tank has a capacity of 12,000 ga
